title: JESUS FORGIVES AND HEALS A PARALYSED MAN. Part 5
scripture_text:
A few days later, when Jesus again entered Capernaum, the people
heard that he had come home. They gathered in such large number that
there was no room left, not even outside the door, and he preached the
word to them, then some men came, bringing to him a paralysed man,
carried by four of them. Since they could not get him to Jesus because
of the crowd, they made an opening in the roof above Jesus by digging
through it and then lowered the mat the man was lying on. When Jesus saw
their faith, he said to the paralysed man, "Son, your sins are
forgiven." Now some teachers of the law were sitting there, thinking to
themselves, "Why does this fellow talk like that? He's blaspheming! Who
can forgive sins but God alone?" Immediately Jesus knew in his spirit
that this was what they were thinking in their hearts, and he said to
them, "Why are you thinking these things? Which is easier: to say to
this paralysed man, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say, 'Get up, take
your mat and walk'? But I want you to know that the Son of Man has
authority on earth to forgive sins." So he said to the man, "I tell
you, get up, take your mat and go home. He got up, took his mat and
walked out in full view of them all. This amazed everyone and they
praised God saying, "We have never seen anything like this!
devotional:
This story teaches us about how Jesus understood himself.

One of the titles Jesus used for himself was the title 'Son of Man.'
80 times in the gospels Jesus calls himself this title. We know from
Luke 5:17 there was a lot of Scribes listening to Jesus. 'He was
teaching, and Pharisees and teachers of the law were sitting among the
crowd. They had come from every village of Galilee and from Judea and
Jerusalem.' The Scribes listening to Jesus would have understood this
claim as a reference to Daniel 7:13-14: - 'In my vision at night I
looked, and there before me was one like a son of man, coming with the
clouds of heaven. He approached the Ancient of Days and was led into his
presence. 14 He was given authority, glory and sovereign power; all
nations and peoples of every language worshipped him. His dominion is an
everlasting dominion that will not pass away, and his kingdom is one
that will never be destroyed.'

So the title had two meanings at a surface level, it simply referred
to Jesus' humanity, but it was also a title of exaltation and victory.
So when these Scribes hear Jesus calling himself 'The Son of Man,' they
knew he was taking on a divine title.

Mark tells us 'the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sin.'
The word authority literately means 'The right to act.'

When we hear the word 'authority,' most of us have negative feelings,
we don't like being told what to do, we want to be our own boss.
However, have you ever thought that the forgiveness sins is one of the
ways that Jesus expresses his authority over our lives.

I am not too sure if we can call Jesus Saviour and not bring all of
our lives under his authority. Being forgiven means that Jesus has
exercises his authority in your life, but it also means that you have
submitted your life to his authority.
prayer:
Father, thank you that being forgiven, is a sign of Jesus'
authority in my life. Help me to submit to His Lordship as I enjoy His
forgiveness.

JESUS FORGIVES AND HEALS A PARALYSED MAN. Part 5

Mark 2:1-12

A few days later, when Jesus again entered Capernaum, the people heard that he had come home. They gathered in such large number that there was no room left, not even outside the door, and he preached the word to them, then some men came, bringing to him a paralysed man, carried by four of them. Since they could not get him to Jesus because of the crowd, they made an opening in the roof above Jesus by digging through it and then lowered the mat the man was lying on. When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralysed man, "Son, your sins are forgiven." Now some teachers of the law were sitting there, thinking to themselves, "Why does this fellow talk like that? He's blaspheming! Who can forgive sins but God alone?" Immediately Jesus knew in his spirit that this was what they were thinking in their hearts, and he said to them, "Why are you thinking these things? Which is easier: to say to this paralysed man, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say, 'Get up, take your mat and walk'? But I want you to know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins." So he said to the man, "I tell you, get up, take your mat and go home. He got up, took his mat and walked out in full view of them all. This amazed everyone and they praised God saying, "We have never seen anything like this!

This story teaches us about how Jesus understood himself.

One of the titles Jesus used for himself was the title 'Son of Man.' 80 times in the gospels Jesus calls himself this title. We know from Luke 5:17 there was a lot of Scribes listening to Jesus. 'He was teaching, and Pharisees and teachers of the law were sitting among the crowd. They had come from every village of Galilee and from Judea and Jerusalem.' The Scribes listening to Jesus would have understood this claim as a reference to Daniel 7:13-14: - 'In my vision at night I looked, and there before me was one like a son of man, coming with the clouds of heaven. He approached the Ancient of Days and was led into his presence. 14 He was given authority, glory and sovereign power; all nations and peoples of every language worshipped him. His dominion is an everlasting dominion that will not pass away, and his kingdom is one that will never be destroyed.'

So the title had two meanings at a surface level, it simply referred to Jesus' humanity, but it was also a title of exaltation and victory. So when these Scribes hear Jesus calling himself 'The Son of Man,' they knew he was taking on a divine title.

Mark tells us 'the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sin.' The word authority literately means 'The right to act.'
